name: Space Rangers HD: A War Apart
description: Space adventure, open world RPG, strategy, arcade, quest and more!
minimum_requirements: OS:Windows XP SP3 Processor:Intel Pentium 4 2.5 GHz / AMD Athlon XP 3200+ (2200 MHz) Memory:1 GB RAM Graphics:GeForce 7800 GT 512 Mb / Radeon 1800 Pro 512 Mb or similar DirectX®:9.0c Hard Drive:2 GB HD space
recommended_requirements: OS:Windows XP SP3 / Windows 7 / Windows 8 Processor:Intel Core 2 Duo E6600 2.4 GHz / AMD Athlon 64 X2 4800+ 2.4 GHz Memory:2 GB RAM Graphics:GeForce 8600 GT 512 Mb / Radeon X3550 Pro 512 Mb DirectX®:9.0c Hard Drive:3 GB HD space

reviews.review_text: I spent no less than 1000 hours playing this game back in 2007 and I feel so good having this game back now, a better one. I spent hours doing and caculating trades for maximum profit, I digged all the text quests like a crazy miner, I blew the whole galaxy up. If you played this game before you know the feeling when you got a massive hull with all available slots with high armor, it feels FREAKING GOOD BABY! And that moment when you caught a superb deal of trade and you see your credit account cha-ching up, it feels ♥♥♥♥ING GOODDDDDD!  This game isn't a MMO but it makes you feel like you're playing a MMO game.  ♥♥♥♥! This game taugh me so many things about life!

I had played the original Space Rangers 2 Reboot, which this HD release improves upon. Despite it's faults, I really enjoyed the game and put a lot of hours into it. A War Apart adds new content and some bugfixes which makes for a better experience. The Pirate clan added to the game gives it more depth and makes it much more fun to be an actual pirate in the game. You may join them, or you may use their territory as a safe zone. The original game made it very difficult to pirate efficiently. Still, the Dialog remains a little on the dodgy side, not much has changed there. If you played the Reboot and enjoyed it, this is a recommended purchase. For someone new to Space Rangers however, this is a solid game with quite a few modes of play. Whether your quests can take you to do an RTS section or a Text adventure, you aren't forced to do them if they're not your cup of tea. I will say this is a game for an older gamer, and it shows it's age even in this re-release.

Space Rangers is at its basics an adventure/RPG set in space. The game is centered around a galactic struggle with a mechanized race known as the Dominators which showed up out of nowhere to give the five main galactic races a pounding. The Space Rangers are the first line of defense against these invaders and are pretty much an autonomous organization built as military and trade support. Players will need to climb up the Ranger ranks, gain new equipment, kill lots of dominators, help research thrive, and eventually take out the three main Dominator command units. How that happens is very open for interpretation.

'Admiral Piett: Our ships have sighted the Millennium Falcon, my lord. But, it has entered an asteroid field and we cannot risk... Darth Vader: Asteroids do not concern me, Admiral. I want that ship, not excuses.'
Best of russian classics. Very well made and balanced continue of Space Rangers.
Such a fun game! Wish there was more like this. Only game I've ever missed work for.

Guys, if you haven't nominated any games in the recent Steam Awards, give this game a chance at 'Game Within A Game'!  Space Rangers HD has so much mini-games in the game, it's the only game worthy of this title! Inside a seemingly sandbox space RPG are Real Time Strategy planetary battle, text quests, and mini shooter game!  ---  Several game types all packed into one great game.  + Combines several game genres including turn-based space combat / trading, text quests, and planetary RTS battles, all merged flawlessly + Except the main component (turn-based space combat) all others are (kind of) optional + A variety of difficulty choices: you can even customize parts of game components such as quest difficulty and enemy strength + Customizing your ship with random loots is fun + Ability to interact with (and even command) some NPC ships + Lively world that would work itself out, even without your input. NPCs go about their businesses that can have as much impact to the world as the player. + Despite the seemingly simple combat mechanic, those with a tactical mind can still gain an edge  - AI could use some work, but has improved quite a bit since release - Outdated (but workable) 2D graphic - Text quests is sometimes confusing due to poor translation (even though it has been improved over the previous release)  Now if further improvement to AI is implemented...
♥♥♥♥ing Epic! One of the best Russian games so far. Remastered in a very honest way: added ♥♥♥♥ tons of new stuff. And finally you can finish game as a badass pirate.
One of the best game ever! Playing since my very first PC (Pentium I, yep, 200Mhz)
I played this as I kid and I still play it. I said everything...
The only Space SIM Type of Game I ever loved to play. No Space games have lived up to this game yet in my opinion. 10/10 should play this

I played this game several years ago and I was positively impressed already back then by its variety and different types of things that could be done. Unfortunately my English knowledge did not allow me to enjoy and play the game at the time. Now things are changed and I am really enjoying the HD version of this game (which works on Windows 8). I am often loosing track of time while playing it :).

Excellent game, warts and all. My only real complaint are about the text quests, some of which are capriciously random (I'm looking at you, fishing quest!). The rest of the game is quite fun, so long as you keep in mind that the universe is not a nice place and if you ♥♥♥♥ off certain factions it has a noticeable impact on galactic events.  Edit: The game also has the npcs keep up with your tech level, so if you upgrade several pieces of gear, expect the npcs to gain better shields or weapons (in my case, it typically shields, which made chasing pirates a chore).

Space Rangers combines a unique set of games - to the point where you can't actually call it a Turn-based strategy game, Real-time strategy game, adventure, action, simulation... in the vein of much older games like Sid Meier's Pirates!, it has a core game that is turn-based strategy with a half-dozen smaller games included. Players can choose multiple violent paths to fame and fortune, or even track and predict market variability in an effort to make money through trading.  The whole is even greater than the sum of its parts, and the remake introduced a third faction and an improved translation to the mix. Highly recommended!

Have all of the to date iterations of Space Rangers 2; HD, Reboot, and Rise of the Dominators. They all have varying tweaks/differences that make them worth playing, especially if you get 'em on sale. Thank goodness for developers with OCD. Don't care that much for the planetary battles so I avoid them after the first (requirement for recruit training and nets easy early experience/cash). This relatively inexpensive series is definitely a keeper. Gotta give it a strong 84/100, imho.
unique game Like old school Fallout, but in space
The only game on this planet that got the whole 'choose your own journey' right. If there was a nuclear war and you would only be allowed to take one game with you into the bunker, it'd be this.

I would rank this game absolute number 1 among all the games I played.  If you like RPG, RTS, arcades or turn-based games and never tried a mixture of all of them, then you must play this one.  This game offers everything is small portions, so if you don't like a part of it, your impression of the entire game will not be spoiled. If you hate RTS or text quests, it is entirely possible to skip all missions that offer those. If you don't like turn-based fighting, then choose a peaceful path of a trader. Alternatively, if you are down to kick some butt, just bully all pirates on your way and destroy dominators. There are countless ways to play the game and I bet anybody will find a way to enjoy it.   This is the only game that got me hooked into its immersive, well thought-out and filled with humour world.  I spent countless hours (possibly 100s) playing the 1st and 2nd part of this series, and I can say that Space Rangers HD is just more balanced among both with better graphics, alternative ending and more weapons. Devs really spend a lot of time working on balance fixes and minor bugs here and there (check patch history).   Overall well polished and diverse game.  10/10 buy with confidence

Another steam chat paste: space rangers is a really fun game where you can be anything from a corsair pillaging trade to a pirate in the union taking over planets to a space ranger fighting off pirates and the dominators that are taking over the galaxy to a trader that finances the war to a leader of other rangers into battle  the planets also offer missions that you can take such as transport, kill X ship, protect a system for a time, text/click based adventures filled with puzzles and some (somewhat annoying) rts battles, all completly option

a nearly perfect space adventure game. it's too good that i can't describe it here. basically u be a pilot and blah blah blah. however, i'd be soooooo happy if there's a MMO game like this one, or rather make this one's multiplayer game.
Can't decide what kind of game you want to play? Why not try them all in one game? This game is a unique experience. It'll leave a lasting impression on you. Try it out!
It's a really fantastic game about space! 12 Rangers of 10
Great game for those that love space games and loved the previous Space ranger Games
Great Russian Game!

I played this a long time ago and had some fond memories of it. Now I bought it again in the HD version. It does look nice, however, I have decided I hate the text adventures as well as the RTS missions.   I was really into leveling up and getting better stuff for a while, but then the tech progression got really slow and there just was not much to buy. To make matters worse the way the game does ship maintainace, it is a percent of the value of everything.   After a while just flying around and having normal wear and tear lead to huge expenses.  In the end, I just got bored of doing the same thing over and over without completing the main story line. I could never 'solo' sectors of dominators and trying to find one where other NPCS we helping out seemed like blind luck. I just got bored of it all and put the game down. For good I think.  I would say, buy it when it is on sale. I really like the idea of the game, its just that the execution was quite rough with just too many annoying things.
Open world gameplay. Dynamic universe lends itself to immersion. Aesthetically pleasing for 2D graphics.

In my TOP5 games of all time.  The base version is great in itself. This HD remaster adds some gimmicky stuff (beside resoulution upgrade which shines in RTS portion of the game), soundtrack and a few other questionable improvements which I wouldn't mind being without. I didn't like the way they changed some of the art and was, until recently, praying for them to add an option to switch with vanilla art, as it seemed a tad more immersive. BUT! the studio behind this remaster is still developing free content for this game and since its release, content progressed quite a bit!  All in all, the resolution upgrade alone makes it worth, especially if you're a fan of the series as I am (and can stomach poor art choices for some base/planet backgrounds and loading screens).  REPLAYABILITY POTENTIAL IS CRAZY HIGH  P.S. Don't underestimate the Adventure portion of this game, its one of its strong points. Feel free to disregard RTS though, its not everyones cup of tea and both the AI and UI is quite primitive (though the AI is hard to beat in many cases!).

What can I say about Space Rangers?  Well, my first contact with the game series had been established sometime in 2003/4. I played SR1 a bit and quickly moved on to SR2, which was not an actual sequel but an update. A fact which remained true for every following 'sequel,' didn't know that at the time.  I played SR2 quite extensively over the years, one of two games to which I returned quite often, the other being GTA SA. Once I got a whiff of SR2 Reboot, English version of which trailed behind the Russian release, I grew impenitent over obtaining a copy. Finally it came around on Stardock's Impulse service where, after some proxy shenanigans, I managed to obtain a license of the aforementioned software, leading to quite a lot pleasurable game time.  Of course SR TWA was supposed to be played with burning passion as well. Burning indeed. The game has been extensively updated (both in content and regarding technical aspects) over the years and made even more interesting. To those players who may be inclined toward this type of games.  What type of game is it, you ask, impatient reader? Well, it's an SF roguelike RPG space trader sim riddled with textual quests and packed with arcade and RTS battles. It basically covers all known game genres, with possible exception of triple x rated games, FPS shooters and sports sims. No, you can not play football in SR universe, sorry about that.  Of course not all of these components have been well executed, but that's just how the cookie crumbles. Imagine if the RTS battles didn't suck, the game would be even more attractive and demand even more time. That would just suck. You realize, something has to suck.  Pros: - everything excluding what's listed below  Cons: - I wish the devs had access to more resources so that they may translate ALL the game content into English, instead of having to opt for leaving a part of it out. The game is Russian centric, but instead of seeing this as something negative, one should take this fact for what it is - an excellent opportunity to learn Russian  - as it has been mentioned a number of times, RTS mode sucks. However, it's completely optional, which one doesn't get to see in modern games that often. If at all. These missions can be challenging and rather rewarding, but most of them are quite a chore due to incredibly bad controls and pathing issues  - some consider the arcade black hole mode to be bad, but I personally disagree. While arcade mode is nothing extra super special, it can be a nice way to obtain some otherwise unattainable equipment and provide a break of standard space faring. My qualm over this are possible balancing issues, since you can get quite expensive gear out of the hole fairly early in the game by investing next to nothing into it. Another thing that sucks a bit is the fact that all those weapons which are great in the hole are otherwise useless. And vice versa, so having nice end-game weapons can make the hole problematic to complete. Maybe this was intended by design, IDK really  - I can live with the game being random, however some bits are simply not random. You're practically being cheated now and againg. Two examples: 1. some micromodules are not (to the best of my knowledge and experience) attainable from Ranger Centers. There are a few modules (Universe, Broing, Strongster (which may not be in the game anymore, not sure)) which you'll get to see on about one out of three playthroughs. In ten years playing various versions I got something like 2-3 Universe modules, Broing probably only once and Strongster definitively only once. Not nice, especially since you can regularly come across (usually) pirates having half a dozen of these 2. some dominator gear simply won't drop while using distress signal. I typically check what do they carry before engaging, usually looking for the holy grail of SR (namely the Vertix weapon fixture.) Once I find one that's type H and below 160 weight I spam that dominator with distress signals but the item in question is simply not jettisoned. I understand that obtaining such a powerful weapon too early may pose balancing issues, but that item is quite heavy and expensive to maintain, so it's really not nice to have something like that pulled on an unsuspecting Ranger. Not nice indeed  Room for expansion: - one thing I can't understand is why (after defeating the dominators and before actually finishing the game) existing races stay friendly instead of simply having a showdown, with petty feuding, consorting and what not. That would provide for some after-game entertainment and it would be quite logical conclusion - RTS components in actual space. Something like: 'I have more credits than common sense and want to render this and that system dominator/pirates/coalition proof by means of heavily armored battle stations, private combat ships and what not)' - a unified node account so that your Ranger node account can be used to draw required resources for all your needs, including upgrades and maintaining equipment. It seems silly and cumbersome to lug around 1200 nodes to the nearest science stations to have something upgraded. Seems almost like a bug instead of a missing feature  I think that's about it. As for the sheer size of the world and content, I have to say that even after ten years there's new stuff (not something strictly related to the latest expansion) and game mechanics I encounter from time to time.  Nine out of ten. It took so much time from my life I simply can not rate it any higher than that.

Spacerangers is a simple concept of a 2D space game taken to the extreme . Don't let that minigame look fool you this game has a $60 worth of content . It has somewhat of a sandbox feel to it because you can progress through the game by fighting dominators,trading,doing quests or just being a pirate .   The main menu has a very nice custom gameplay options which you can use to make it harder or easier on yourself . Also you can get much better starting ship at the cost of some races hating you which is a risk vs reward option .  Probably the most important part of this game is just the fact that it is so visually uniqe and the soundtrack is amazing . It may not be a 3D space game but it still creates very immersive atmosphere .  There are several gameplay types that may appeal to different players . You have a turn based space combat, RTS style ground quests where game completly changes the way it plays , Text Missions for people who enjoy puzzles and twitch space combat inside black holes .  Last but not least is the element of random events. Sometimes you pilot can get a sickness and then you will keep getting money each month as donations from organization fighting that disease. Each time you play the game you may run into a different problem . Sometimes some of the big bosses can come to your system location and kill everyone , forcing you to flee and adapt new tactics .If you set game on hardest diffeculty you can actually loose entire galaxy to pirates & dominators .  It really is a solid game in all aspects . My only complain is that I prefered Dominatos (robots) as main story villains and not Pirates in this expansion . The pirate faction has some issues though because you might get a quest to protect all ships in pirate system which is kidna dumb because its just nearly impossible to do without some serious luck .

This game is absolutely a gem! You can be trader, pirate, military general, secret agent or lone wolf, it's up to you. You can kill enemies in direct combat, hack their ships, use stimulants to improve your abilities etc. Missions are really good, especially text quests. Some of them are really hard, they'll make you so angry after 30th time of playing them, but when you do pass them, feeling is unique. Land battles are repetitive and boring, in my opinion.  All in all, great game, especially for space lovers.  10/10
Greatest game that no one in the western countries played
This is a very good game!
It's cool.
The best game. ever!
Love this game definitely has potential. easy to lose track of time
A good game to kill some hours, but nothing spectacular.

I paid only for future UPDATE of Game!!!!!!! We really need more story line. At this moment only we play for pirate or parody to be agent of Coalition Forces. Pirate's way is more comfortable in first part of game, agent's storyline is more strange and brutal in the middle of game. I dont make this game ends more then one. Couse, every two months of real life i've tired of troubles with npc-agents or pirates, some side always having a great overpower on normal or middle difficulty. Not much upgrades (interesting but always ends in the middle of game), not much music (but it's a great music, if your spaceship are not landing to military base!!! Great music!!!). Science stations, business centre and military base e/t/c is not able to upgrade by player's money and weapons for be 100% alive in pirates or dominators attacks. You up the science station with big guns and helath regeneration - but crowd of pirates or ... - wasted money, wasted loot.  I need more from game...  But it's must be played/If you still thinking buy or not - I'll recommend to try this musical masterpiece and interesting graphical design.
best of the best musthave 100%
It's a novel.
So far a good game...graphics are very limited, but the game play makes up for that.  I have only been playing a few hours. It's a little bit like a 2D basic version of Elite.

This game is like a bunch of minigames all thrown together. The main game is a spaceship/trading game, you upgrade your ship and fight in turn based combat. There's a lot of freedom you can be a pirate or trader for example, different ships have different strenghts. There's also a bunch of 'text quest' minigames which are completely optional but can give you good amounts of credits to upgrade your ship, some are really good but others are a bit tedious. There's also optional RTS missions which I don't like much but they are short and give good rewards so I'll try each once and skip it if fail once. The game is a bit of a mixed bag but the main game is solid and oddly addicting. Early on you have to rely a lot on other rangers and military ships to fight the dominators (evil AI) but you can eventually become very powerful and hire up to 6 NPC ships and capture enemy systems by yourself.

I've already put hundreds if not thousands of hours into this game, so when I saw continued interest and some new features for Steam I was seriously pumped. Long story short, this is a universe that really moves and lives on its own without you. I've rushed across galaxies to pick up a new warp drive just to see another ranger get there before me and buy it. I've escaped Galaxies just before they were crushed under robotic oppression. It really is just a great idea and executed well. I wish more games and even other genres would take pointers in their open worlds. Really the only criticism I can give is the ground battles are a little bit uninspired for an rts... they have some good ideas but it just gets very repetitive. But there is literally an option in the game to skip them and never play them, so it's just another example of how they are in touch with their audience.
It's amazing how simplistic graphics can lead to a game such addictive, deep and replayable as this. A hidden gem indeed.
Awesome game. Very nostalgic for me. I love rogue like style this game used. For me one of the best rogue like sci-fi games I ever played.
Most warm and fuzzy game I ever played.
Text-based adventures is where its at.
Great soundtrack, addictive quests, space, pirates and black holes. Welcome
Amazon remake of a great old game. This has every thing, RTS, RPS, Arcade shooter.

Awesome game, very addictive.  Turn based 2D space sort-of-RPG (RPG because your character has a few stats that you increase for XP, you customize equipment of your ship, and because you can roleplay your own path - be a corsair, trader, mercenary, goody-two-shoes hero...), arcade minigame (in back holes), real time strategy missions (sometimes on inhabited planets), old fashioned text based minigames (some missions on inhabited planets, also if you get thrown into prison).  The game world (galaxy is randomly generated for each gameplay) is very alive and goes on regardless of your progress - you can affect it, of course (and various alien races will like or hate you for your actions), but it doesn't stop and wait just because you decided to waste time (or got thrown into prison :D ).  There are basically three warring factions, out of which two you can join, the third are the main bad guys. These factions actively mount offensive and defense of their territory and take over planetary systems from each other (in case of the bad guys there are also three sub-factions that fight each other). At the beginning of a playthrough you are just a small fish in a sea of sharks (on higher difficulties i definitely don't recommend to take part in the war, before you have some decent ship and equipment), and by the end you will be liberating systems pretty much single-handedly.  The economy part of the game (i.e. trading commodities and change of prices) is nicely done. NPC ships fly around trade commodities and buy new equipment (so the equip stores are not just for you - if you see that there is a nice peace of equip on some distant planet, you may want to hurry).  Terrific alien races.  The ship equipment, variety of weapons and variety of equipable or usable artefacts is also very nicely done.  Quality of available equpment changes over playthrough, depending on how much in-game time has passed.  A few negatives that need mentioning though - in RTS part, AI of your units is dumb as a tree stump, much micromanagement required, at least in my experience - in RTS you can't save, so you have to do everything in one go, which is inconvenient (it however also prevents save-scam and thus increases difficulty which is nice, albeit sometimes a little frustrating) - the GUI could be a little confusing for a new player (easy solution, just try out all the buttons on screen and see what they do) - it is easy to mess up the beginning if you don't know what you're doing and the in-game tutorial doesn't cover everything (saving often helps and i'd recommend to start one playthrough on easy and play it at least for an hour or two to learn the basics)

Buy, install, start... Than realize, that this is a great game for Space-maniacs and Text-quest-lovers. Interesting planet battles, huge amount of ship-equipment, wonderfull mini-quests. Even after end, there is still fun!  GOOD LUCK, COMMANDER!

I've nominated this game for “GAME WITHIN A GAME” award: text quests, planet battles and much more. It is one of the best single-player games I've ever played. Too bad it does not have multiplayer mode. I would never miss a chance to play it with my frends.

Here's how you play it:  1. Start a new game in «Ironman» mode with only one autosave slot. 2. Game crashes for no reason every couple of hours, but at least you can continue from the autosave. 3. Spend around 30 hours on your single playthrough. Earn money, rare items, fight bad guys and robots. You became a wealthy person with a nice ship and equipment, and can finally relax a bit. 4. Game finally crashes so hard it freezes Windows and after a reboot, your only autosave is gone. 5. 30 hours well spent.

This game is nothing like the pictures or description make it out to be. Maybe that's alright with people already familiar with the series, but I was sadly disappointed. The user interface is terrible, there's almost no in-game tutorial, and the gameplay is tedious. I have no idea when the tag arcade is added to Space Ranger HD because it's absolutely not arcade-y at all.   Oh, and the RTS mini-game is terrible.

So much promise and content to this game, but the interface is a mess and the grandness of it's scope is directly proportional to how overwhelmed and unable you are to even see or understand what it has to offer. Tries to be a lot of things but doesn't give you a learning curve to get up there. For example, there is a tutorial that teaches you all the basics of how to fight ship to ship, and trade, and do missions, and see how the planetside RTS works... but whatever you actually try is a dismal failure. Do you like trying to grab a bit of mineral debris with repeated commands only to be mystified that it always takes about 3 tries? Is your education in system-based combat of any use when any encounter you wind up in you are likely going to be totally ventilated? Howabout a tutorial on how to play the RTS that literally allows itself to get bogged down until you AND the enemy run out of resources? I wanted to like this game and gave it several shots. Ulitimately life is too short. I had to give up. Try at your own peril.

This is a game I had high hopes for, but it simply let me down. Your game play will consist of running planet to planet praying for a fight of some kind ... someone, anyone to fight. Eventually you will stumble into a system with 6-8 enemy ships and they will all instantly swarm you and kill you. The turn based combat is clunky. The randomly generated gear is often useless ... whole planets have 10-20 items for sale. Do not buy this game for full price, find it in a bundle somewhere. If I had paid full price for this game instead of getting it in a $5 bundle I would be asking for my money back.  The game needs to allow you to use bigger ships, or have more than one ship.

So I tried this game - picked it up on sale at some point - and the first time I played it the TUTORIAL missions sent me to a planet where two enemies attacked and killed me.  'That's a bit ♥♥♥♥ed...' I think to myself. 'How was I supposed to know they were the enemy? They had no markings, they just made a bee line for my ship as soon as I entered the system. Fine, at least I know they're coming, I can be ready for them'.  Yeah, nah, you're ♥♥♥♥ed. Your guns can't do any significant damage to them and your shields are like butter  'Maybe I'm doing something wrong. Perhaps I went to the wrong planet?' Nope, your Instructor decided to send you to a planet orbited by two guys who want nothing more than to ♥♥♥♥ up your day.  So I give it up as a bad idea.  Decided to give it another try today. New game, knowing my instructor is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who will sell me out. Upgrade shields, weapons and engines...  Still ♥♥♥♥ed. Bad guys are even tougher than they were the first time, and I'm somehow doing even less damage.  And all this is still in the first three missions of the tutorial. Aparently all it is going to teach you is that the game, which looks like it could have been a fun top-down space epic, is ♥♥♥♥ed.  Don't waste your money.

Ok... this game might have been good in 2002.  Now it's 2014 and it's production like this which give the genre a bad name.  I played for 2 hours just to give it a good test... here is how it goes. I started a game by choosing at random in a load of what seem to be pointless options. The game proposed me a tutorial after read about a dozen wall of texts. The game even lampshades it's being annoying by doing so. I hurt my eyes looking at the small print everywhere. Then I bought some probes, when to explore mercury (sounded like a good idea) and when outside of mercury, some pirate asked for twice my total money otherwise it kills me. Then a second one joined. Now I can't leave the planet - not that I could beat the first one. After a half hours of tests I managed to kill them (with the help of random military ships in the system) but 2 more joined... and I spend most of my money repairing my ship. It feels like endless grind. I didn't even play 2 hours.  Apart from the obviously bad balancing in this game (really ? getting camped in the STARTING SYSTEM ???), combat done in the tutorial feels VERY bland, just point in a direction and shoot automatically if you didn't forget to ask it to shoot. Inventory is very small, there seems to be about 8 things possible to trade, repair costs are prohibitive, mini-games... uhg. I started the 'robot war' thingy. Ok, it kind of does allow for infinite money in the main game at the cost of not playing the main game. It's about as fun as the 'just before space' war in spore with the Fun part taken out of it. Oh wait, there is no fun part in that phase of spore... and this is even worse. Trading is... trading. Mining is shooting at ships and waiting for more asteroids to come. Exploration consists in loading probes and clicking 'end turn' until it's done - and mostly you can't take everything beause inventory is sooo small. And the walls of text in very small print which hurt my eyes on top of it.  I imagine that some of the defects I speak of are alleviated later in the game, but the start did such a good job in disgusting me I can't even think of going to look.  I can't recommend this. It's game like that which keeps the space games down. I'm glad I got it in a sale for 5 euros, but it's not even worth this low amount of money.  PS: Sadly, this game shows the limitations of the review system in Steam. When a game has a 'cult' following a load of hardcore fans flock to the game, block bad reviews, and flood the store with 'good' reviews. Don't be fooled, this game is fully deserving of the low reviews it deserves on metacritic.

I really wanted to like this game. No, I REALLY wanted to like this game. It reminded me of another space exploration/ combat/ merchant game I used to love to play called Escape Velocity. This was slightly different, what with the turn based movement/ combat and a RTS-type aspect with the ground combat. But I thought that would just add to the enjoyment.   My biggest problem with this game (and the reason I uninstalled it) is that they tell you nothing about anything. You are thrown to the wolves from day one. They do have a minor tutorial that 'instructs' you how to play. It took me dying 5 times in the tutorial (THE TUTORIAL) to realize that most of the useful information is displayed as a microscopic toolbar down in the bottom left of your screen. After I saw that, I actually managed to make it past the tutorial only to die promptly thereafter to a random pirate (this wasn't in hard mode, mind you). Also, there are so many little markings and symbols that don't have a description. These things should be helping you, but instead just make me ask, 'Why give me descriptors that are in no way descriptive or helpful?' There are 2 very different combat modes (one of which they don't bother explaining at all). All-in-all, this game was just massively frustrating.  This could be an AMAZING game. All they would have to do is help you understand how the game works. Instead, they throw you the (incomplete) Dummies guide to brain surgery and say, 'good luck, sucker.' I will gladly pick it up again if I learn that they have added an actual descriptive explanation of how to play the game.
